column3: This is a must see in Santa Monica and definitely the best hike in this area. Been three times and still want to visit more. Stunning views as far as the eye can see.

We drove through the mountains on our way to Malibu. This was one of the highlights. The scenery was just beautiful, the sun beaming down on the mountains was absolutely picturesque. We had a convertible so we were able to experience them better. Stopped a couple of times to take pictures.
The beautiful mountains really highlight this impressive [art of southern California! They are hard to miss
Everyone should take a few hikes up in these mountains, the views are incredible and there are many!

It is amazing how you quickly one can leave busy and noisy LA behind - and getting into Santa Monica Mountains is one of those ways. Variety of different level of hikes, most of them offering great views to the Pacific Ocean. Parking is usually not a problem at all. Highly recommended.

Our two hour hike was filled with great views from the mountains, to the city and the ocean. The vistas were grand! The terrain was slightly uphill on the way in and we chose the sloping hills for a little challenge on the way back. Great walk for all levels. Loved all the dogs on the trail. I would do this hike again and again.
First time out to Cali,great trails,great sights.Easy parking and access for first time users.!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Being from Florida I really enjoyed hiking there. Great place for a morning work out. Very well maintained!
The Santa Monica Mountains are just beautiful. Looking at them just a wow factor. We could see them every morning, from the hotel and beach.
The Getty View Trail is a favourite. Easy for most, could be a bit challenging for others. Great views!
Excellent hiking trails and beauty in nature and quiet serenity to soothe your soul. Enjoy getting into the mountains and finding waterfalls :)
Always great to see a mountain vista and traverse mountain roads en route to the sea, or stop along the way to discover trails and local flora. Quintessential LA.

column2: The Mountains and Trail Opportunities Stretch Out Forever!
column3: I love hiking and taught my son, as a solo parent, how to hike which as a young boy helped work off a lot of his angst and for me? A lot of my nerves. There are so many areas within the Santa Monica Mountains to see while you're driving or to take the time to picnic or hike with friends, a group, moonlit hikes, a lover or significant other or your kids.Every stop along the way you'll find maps or can online to map out your destination for a day.
hiking this visually amazing place was the highlight of my trip. Seeing the seals from the top of the mountain was the best memory.

These mountains are breathtakingly beautiful! There are so many car pull offs along the road that you have no reason not to stop. There are numerous hiking trails, most are easy to navigate and some are a little moderate. Great picture opportunities everywhere you look.

Incredibly beautiful! A very nice change of scenery from the concrete of the city, the beach and loads of traffic. Although not as high as most mountains, the gorgeous thing is they are so very close to the water.
Such lovely views as you explore the region. Lots of traffic even during the week - good thing we weren't in a hurry. Parking was limited at some trailheads.

Beautiful vista's rivalling my memories of the Alps, Santa Monica Mountains end of the Route 66 trail for us. Walked the dogs thru them as a pet friendly location then had a picnic. Part of the foothills of the Rockies

column2: Santa Monica Mountains Make Us Healthy!
column3: Our group hikes weekly in these beautiful, yet nearby mountains.Thanks to all who obey the rules and keep trash and graffiti out.We enjoy the fresh air and many plants and occasional sightings of special birds, rabbits, and lizards. Because the paths are connected, one can do a shorter hike or a very long one. Also, there are many different locations to start from. Thanks to those who preserved these mountains for our use. We especially enjoy seeing people of all ethnicities and also children hiking in these mountains.

We drove through the mountains to enjoy the view of the ocean and area. The drive was very leisurely despite what one thinks about the fast pace in California. Many place available to stop and enjoy nature.
Been to Santa Monica mountains 2 times while we were driving back and forwards to Chatsworth and further inner places.Nice change from the flat beach geography.

A very nice change of scenery from the concrete of the city, the beach and loads of traffic.Although not as high as other mountain ranges in the country, the neat thing is they are so very close to the city and they are abundant. Great views with canyons galore, rock formations, wooded areas and scrubs. It has it all. Great for hiking, having a picnic, sightseeing, or just going for a ride. Many areas to check out.
Nice uphill terrain, very dusty. so don't bring your good sneekers. bring water and a good hat. it is a lot more fun going down the trails than up.

A surprisingly fun set of hiking trails for all fitness levels. Easy to access with Public Transport or by car. The views in all directions are spectacular and there's a Farmer's Market nearby where you could get a healthy snack afterwards.

column2: Mountain hikes with views of Santa Monica
column3: Will Rogers Park on Sunset Blvd. will get you into the mountain trails, as will Topanga Canyon Rd. or Temescal Canyon.

column2: Mishe Mokwa to Backbone Trail Loop. Excellent
column3: If you are looking for a longish hike with varied and beautiful views, this is for you.What to know:I'm 50 and in moderately good shape.The high was 65 and breezy with some cloud cover.I did it in running shoes, shorts and added and removed a layer several times mostly due to the wind. Several times I wished for light hiking boots but was fine with a little more attention to foot placement.Take plenty of water and snacks.The 6+ miles took 4.5 hours from start to finishIt is a beautiful walk with lots of variation from plants to high peaks and outcroppings to see. Every few hundred yards there is a new vista. About 20% of this walk is shaded if you start at 8AM as I did. Still, you are exposed a lot so sunblock is important.Most of the trails have a narrow gravel/rock free lane. However, you will definitely deal with some unsure footing along the way.Split Rock and Balance Rock are two different things. If you are up for something a little more technical (but totally do-able), cut off the trail to Balance Rock. It is the best thing on the trail. It will be a 45 minute diversion.I added a few hints on the attached image. Enjoy !

column2: A great afternoon to see th e sights and get exercise!
column3: Spent the afternoon hiking up to the top of a mountain and relished the views of LA, Santa Monica, and Malibu. Not for the casual walker, these hills can be quite steep. The trip to the top is worth it but be aware that the trip downhill can be equally taxing on your knees. Enjoy the beauty nature has to offer!

We did the Mishe Mokwa trail and backbone trail. It was close to 8 miles and 75 floors according to my iPhone app. Great view from the top. You can see Catalina as well as some beautiful terrain of the Santa Monica mountains. One of southern California’s beautiful trails.

Take a morning or afternoon ride to one of the many parks nestled in the mountains. Try Santa Monica Creek S.P. for a hike to the MASH filming site. It's just nice to get away from the Ocean Ave. and Rodeo Drive crowds and enjoy the natural beauty of the area

column2: A simply beautiful hike at the Grotto
column3: This hike is very enjoyable because of the water and the shade trees! It’s totally worth the drive and can be done in a couple of hours. It’s a moderate hike, so get ready to sweat a little!

column2: Fun place to hike and see the Santa Monica Bay
column3: There are many places to hike in the Santa Monica mountains. One if just at the end of Temescal Canyon Road. There is free parking on the street and a parking lot where you can pay. Absolutely beautiful views of the entire Santa Monica bay area, and if the weather is good, you can see Catalina Island. If you are into nature, this a place to go see.

column2: rent a car & drive the less traveled canyon roads
column3: There are about 8-10 roads running north / south from Pacific Coast Highway ( Malibu area ) up to 101 . Avoid 27 ( well developed ) and try some of the lesser known roads like Kanan Dume Road or Rt 23 or Corral Canyon Road .Let your girls stalk the Kardashians up in Calabasas / Hidden Hills & stop by Lovis for a snack .We had some great pictures up off some side roads looking down canyons with Pacific off in distance .
Decided to hike the Santa Monica mountains on a Sunday afternoon. The trails were not very crowded and offered some excellent views of the Pacific Ocean.

column2: Sandstone Peak tp the Griffith Park Observatory
column3: Sandstone Peak to the Griffith Park Observatory, the Santa Monica Mountains they provide a backdrop for Los Angeles. Both the Getty Villa and the Getty Museum are situated in the Santa Monica mountains. Terrific hiking in Malibu Creek State Park out to the MASH filming site. Something for everyone.

I have been staying in Laurel canyon and sad to say it is now part of the automotive rat race that has consumed LA. For better and less crowded driving head to the canyons out of Malibu. If you are one who enjoys driving around to see new vistas the canyons in these mountains will not disappoint. Discovered a community in Topanga canyon that seems to have an artsy/hippie(?) type. Following Mulholand Drive is another fine way to see the best of LA.

Having visited the Sequoia, the Kings canyon and Yosemite earlier on that week, I must say I was also impressed with these mountains.We really enjoyed mainly the drive from the Big sur and coming down onto Santa Barbara, then Malibu, reaching Santa Monica and nothing let us down. Great drive with the mountains on the left as you reach Malibu, with Getty's villa domineering the cliff and the ocean on the right. You have some amazing houses on the cliffs and I am sure hiking inland would not disappoint either.We surely want to come back, stay in this area and maybe do some hiking.

First of all, this is L.A., not Yosemite, so keep your expectations mild. You'll get ocean views from this hike, but also lots of homes, and urban smogscapes. This trail is far gentler on the up slope than its companion ridge trail. And it passes a seasonal waterfall. Your best access is off of Sunset and Temescal Canyon but, if you are driving in, bypass the first two lefts and head for the back parking. Also, be aware that you are expected to pay a $10 fee. If you start here, rather than at the first lots, you'll be able to follow the signage and not wander off on one of the many spur trails. Like I said, the trail is only of moderate stress, but the views don't open until you're nearly to the ridge. Once there you can hike a much longer distance up top. At least get to Skull Rock and, perhaps, farther. Maybe try a spur to a higher ridge line. There is a back way down, but you'll be miles away from your parking. So I advise returning back to the ridge junction and hike down the ridge trail. Here, the views are continual and you probably won't be much impacted on the downhill trek; though the people hiking up this way most probably will. By the way, I didn't drive here. Both the # 2 Metro and 9 Big Blue buses stop in front of the parking.
The enviroment changes greatly as you travel inland from the ocean. Inland can be very hot and dry. Be on the lookout for rattle snakes, and we once saw a mountain lion.

This hike is close to the Malibu beaches. It's about a 20 minute drive up to the trailhead on Yerba Beuno road. They say its the highest point in Los Angeles County (about 3200 feet). There is free parking and a porta-potty at the trailhead. Once you reach the top, the views are spectacular in all directions.However, the trail has been severly rutted by the spring rains. They have filled in most of the ruts with loose rock - which makes for an uncomfortable hike in sandals or Keens. Best to have actual hiking shoes.
The drive through the the mountains down to Malibu is absolutely fabulous. When you get your first glance of the Pacific through the mountains, it is breathtaking.

With a number of lengthy trails, and great 360 degree views or LA, what else could you ask for? Hiking on the trails of Santa Monica Mountains is a great way to start the day, and an even better reason to head to either Santa Monica or Malibu for a post hike brunch/lunch.The reward is making it to the top or hitting your goal for the day, but the views overlooking the ocean, and parts of LA are truly incredible as well.
I will never get tired of the views! they are breathtaking! great pictures and so so serene. Will always love the mountain views!

While in the LA area, you should spare some time to explore these beautiful mountains. The Topanga Canyon overlook is the best viewpoint, but you cannot go wrong no matter where you view these amazing creations from our God. Enjoy!

I stayed at Sycamore canyon campground and spent one day hiking a loop north of it. It was late March, about +20C and sunny, and the views were breathtaking. There is a nice observation point up and to the West of the campground, looking over the beach and the ocean. Further inland one finds beatiful mountain landscapes. And at this time of year the wild flowers were in full bloom, covering some slopes in natural flowerbeds from top to bottom, and only bright pinpricks in other places.
There are many trails to take when you feel like a great hike! All of them offer an amazing views, some of the ocean, some of the mountains. It's always an enjoyable hike!

What a unique and beautiful place and experience! The landscape of sagebrush, native wildflowers, ancient oaks, and majestic rock formations are a one of a kind. The whole area is clean, but not altered. You have the feeling that the native Americans that walked those trails hundreds of years ago would look pretty much the same. The location has been preserved, and yet has the modern convenience of a bathroom at the entrance. The rangers who you might see from time to time are friendly, knowledgeable, and have a passion for what they do. To me the land has always seemed magical from the first time I visited it through Audubon Society many years ago. Great place to take family, whether another 2-legged, or 4-legged companion because you can get a nice work out, but not over stenuous.

Filled with glorious walking and hiking trails, the summits will give you a panoramic view of the Pacific Ocean and plenty of opportunities to spot quail, deer and hawks along the way. For an accessible hike, try the Sara Wan Trailhead, a 2.5-mile loop with parking and picnic facilities.How to Get There: 25623 Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu. Take Pacific Coast Highway north toward Malibu and turn inland 4.5 miles west of Malibu Canyon Road. There’s a parking lot on north side of highway.Before You Visit: Bring some cash, as there might be a small fee to enter and park.

column2: Lived here and loved driving these mountains
column3: There are wonderful views here, winding roads, fun parks 'tucked' into the mountains and walks. It really is worth driving through.

column2: Mishe Mokwa Trail and Sandstone Peak - great hike
column3: We did this wonderful hike in the Santa Monica mountains on a hot Friday; we set off around 11 am or so and there weren't too many people on the trail. It's not a difficult hike, and took us about 3 - 3.5 hours. Starting at the Sandstone Peak trailhead, we turned right at the fork and did the Mishe Mokwa trail first, which meets up with the Backbone Trail to form a loop back to the trailhead. The Backbone Trail takes you to Sandstone Peak, the highest point in the Santa Monica mountains with spectacular views. There's a little box at Sandstone Peak with a visitor log in it for hikers to sign. Going this direction, counter clockwise, means a more gradual ascent to the high point.The trail map can be found on the NPS website under Circle X Ranch.Highway 23 through the mountains is very twisty! The first time we drove it, going from Westlake Village to Zuma Beach, we went a bit too fast and my head was spinning by the end. Second time we took it a bit slower!

column2: One of Highway 1's Crown Jewels, Hiking, photography
column3: Great for exercise, views and natural beauty.Easy to access and no cost to truly embrace Southern California's Golden coast

column2: Good to see after some rain
column3: We have been walking here for many years. Pretty sad after fire and drought. Now after the rains great to see everything turning green. Especially enjoy seeing the wayerfalls and streams flowing. God is good.

column2: Great Hike with Ocean and City View
column3: I went on this hike with a Networking Group on a Sunday. The hike is free to public. The location is just off Pacific Coast Highway up Sunset Blvd, on 566 Los Liones Dr, Pacific Palisades, CA 90272. I suggest getting there early for closest free street parking. We arrived at 9:15 and parked pretty close to the trail head. Drive up the hill until you see the Church on your left. Bring water and a camera. Not a difficult hike. The trail is fairly long so you can choose your distance. Great views of coast, Catalina, the City Downtown and surrounding Mountains. No Dogs or pets allowed.
I'm so lucky to live here! I can hike different trails any day of the week, even in the rain! Highly recommend!

Really to recommend for hiking. Several trails, some of them a bit demanding. All trails offer great views over the mountain range and some over the sea as well. Once on the top of the tri peaks summit, "climb" a bit down behind them for some nice caves!

Rented a car from Hertz with GPS and was looking for something to do and it gave me this. Well.., it was the most frightening drive I've ever done. It is a very curvy road with lots of turns and twist. Take it slow. The views were amazing - how do they build the homes there and who lives there. If you don't mind driving this is pretty cool. Even on a foggy day.

Went to the Malibu Park to hike to the former Mash film set. It was very hot, you need to bring water and there is one steep climb. We did this is 2.5 hours including a diversion to the dam. Very good exercise and the walk was very scenic.

We frequent the Santa Monica Mountains and it's always a treat for hiking trails, lookout points and being a part of Nature! There are many roads to explore - Decker Canyon Rd. which takes you thru hills & valleys from Westlake Village to the Pacific Ocean. Kanan Road winds thru the hills from Agoura Hills to Malibu & Zuma Beach. Lots of walking & hiking paths and view pull off spots along the way. Malibu Canyon Rd. runs from Las Verginas to Pacific Coast Hwy with walking, hicking trails along a beautiful drive thru the Santa Monica Mountains to Malibu and the Pepperdine university and great shops & restaurants in Malibu. There are beautiful creatures such as mountain lions, coyotes, bobcats, deer and which are living in their habitat! A great way to see nature in our backyard! Fun! Fun!

column2: Amazing views on the Mishe Mokwa Trail!
column3: I've always thought the Santa Monica Mountains were kinda blah....Solstice Canyon being totally trashed w/graffiti, trash, and random parties going on w/loud music around the ruins....although it does offer nice ocean views, it just felt like any other "city hike." Boy was I WRONG though. The Mishe Mokwa Trail to Sandstone Peak is absolutely GORGEOUS! The road to get to the trailhead is pretty gnarly and narrow so if you're not used to mountain driving it may bring some sweat to your hands & a faster heart rate. I've tried getting there from both PCH & the freeway, and both are gnarly. The parking lot is very easy to find as there is a fairly large sign that says "Sandstone Peak Trailhead." Pit toilets are available at the parking lot. This trail is quite busy during the weekend but has way less traffic on the weekdays.After climbing a little less than 0.5 miles, the trail splits: making a right will take you to the Mishe Mokwa trail (longer but gradual incline) and making a left will take you to Sandstone Peak (shorter & steeper grade). I always make a right and follow the Mishe Mokwa trail and do a loop. Doing the loop is about 6.5 to 7 miles, depending on which places you decide to visit. I DEFINITELY recommend doing the Mishe Mokwa trail instead of going directly to Sandstone Peak since you will be missing out on SO much beautiful scenery! You will have a chance to see Split Rock, have the option to go visit the Balancing Rock, and also have the opportunity to check out Tri Peaks. Inspiration Point is another beautiful stop before reaching Sandstone Peak. It's not as crowded as Sandstone Peak and yet has the 360 view of the surrounding area. Highly recommend stopping here.Lots of solitude if you can come during the weekdays. The trail is fairly exposed so I probably wouldn't do this in hot weather. The terrain is very rugged in certain sections with lots of loose rocks...not the best trail when you have an IT band and ankle problem. Coming down from Sandstone Peak to the main trail may be a challenge if you don't have shoes with good traction.Total Miles - 7.1 miles (stopping by Tri-Peaks)Total Elevation - 1,621 ftAdventure Pass is not required to park. Dogs allowed on leash. Hiking permit not required.Amazing rock formations! Go visit!!

column2: Really nice for hiking and still pretty accesible and close to L.A. and Santa Monica!!
column3: Really nice for hiking and still pretty accesible and close to L.A. and Santa Monica!!I really enjoyed the trails and some of the views of both the Pacific Ocean and sometimes Downtown L.A. when hiking here!

column2: If you can do the hike to the top it's worth it!
column3: I've only hiked up to the top once and although the day was super hot the view from the top is worth it. It's beautiful and breezy.Take a lot of water to drink and maybe rinse off a bit once you reach the top, and a picnic lunch, something to sit on, bug spray, sunscreen, sunglasses, and a hat..... to be safe maybe take pepper spray or something to scare a mountain lion away?Stuff does happen, although not often. Don't hike down after dark!Watch for animals, there have been a few issues but there weren't any problems where we were. Mostly issues with mountain bikers.I've heard it is also a great place to become engaged, especially on an early hike to the top. Have fun!

Stayed in Calabasas and did a hike to the canyon. Never hiked any canyon before, so this was the premiere. Me and my friends really liked it. Also it is very nice to drive through the canyon by car from Calabasas to Malibu. Right after you enter Malibu, there is an amazing spot with great view. Also you can stop near Pepperdine university campus, from which you also have perfect view of Malibu and ocean.
Sandstone Peak trail is 3 miles round trip hike . The trip climbs steeply but very nice view on the higher point of Santa Monica Mountains.

column2: Nice few hours hike in Santa Monica Mountains
column3: We had a nice hike at the Malibu Creek State Park which is part of Santa Monica mountains. Was nice to see the location for the TV show MASH site in Malibu Creek State Park

Wonderful shops and restaurants but not for the slight of pocket. Expensive part of L.A. so you don't find cheap shopping, but there is great stuff... everything from clothing to housewares to restaurants.
we took a guided tour thru the mountains that ended with a hike around the SM mountains and it was amazing

I made it through the Santa Monica Mountains quite by accident. I was on my way to a hotel for a business trip and decided to "explore". What I found in these mountains is a majestic wonderland, and quite a hidden secret. Gorgeous majestic mountains with ocean views in the distance. I just had to stop, take a deep breath, soak it all in, and soak in my wanderlust. Nothing like standing on top of a mountainous road overlooking the Pacific Ocean... the meaning of life is in there somewhere....

column2: I could look at them all day
column3: Wait a minute I think I did.Perfect backdrop to the water and city.As good as it gets. Remember this and the water, that's why you came here.Enjoy!

I went for an awesome hike in the Santa Monica Mountains with my brother this spring and I really loved it. The views are gorgeous and it's not too far from the city but far enough that it's less crowded than hikes like Runyon.

column2: Beautiful Park for all of us
column3: What a terrific public park we have at our disposal!!! Well maintained trails, majestic views, beautiful terrain, and just minutes from Los Angeles!!From April-October just respect the fact that there is an occasional Rattlesnake siting. They normally stay away from us like we try to stay away from them. Have lived here most of my life, and have seen only one.Bring plenty of drinking water, CAMALBAKS work great, and just enjoy the day!!
As you drive Pacific Coast Highway 1 northbound the Santa Monica Mountains form a painterly backdrop for Malibu and Malibu Beach.

The Santa Monica mountains provide a scenic backdrop to the north of the Los Angeles area. They also provide a pretty recreational area that has hiking and biking trails and some roads that give a nice overlook to the Los Angeles area.
Traveled the Mulholland Drive from the northern most entry point to Old Topanga Road by motorcycle. You have to love the twisties. If you're there on the weekend, the Rock House will be open.

Definitely worth the climbs up these mountain trails. The paths are wide and the footing is fairly stable. You can get to great view points within about an hour. Be prepared for sun with a hat, sunscreen, and water. There are no restrooms so be prepared for using the good old outdoors if necessary. Although sneakers are ok, it is more stable with some sort of light hiking sandal or shoe.The other interesting fact is that the mountain lion population has grown somewhat with the addition of two baby kittens. They are typically not ever seen;however, this is something to be aware of. We have seen deer and rattlesnakes on the trails.
This is something every person should have on there buck list. There is definitely some breath taking moments I dont even think my pictures do any justice.

There is far more to this area than LA. We spent 2 days driving in the mountains with magnificent views. Visit the ranger stations for maps and information and get away from the crowds.Many hiking trails, ranches, stunt motor cyclists, horseback riding and so many bendy roads. Information about native Indian tribes was very good.

column2: Mountains. How bad can they be?
column3: Not just the mountains, but the entire setting is beautiful. You'll see what I mean once you're there.
There's lots of roads that offer spectacular views, none of which are very busy or touristy which was an added bonus. A highlight of my trip.

column2: There is something here for everyone
column3: There is something here for everyone. If you want to have a smoothie at quark restaurant in Topanga,you can do that, and have fun looking at the trees, and the steep canyons.. If you are looking for amazing sedimentary rock formations, from sandstone to conglomerates, etc

We didn't do much research before our trip and we ended up on road for almost five hours instead of 1 hour as expected. You might want to check those marathon events as it will seriously make you stuck in traffic for ungodly hours.There are too many things to do here, do your own research. We hiked until we saw the Balanced Rock. It was nice but don't expect to be like those fancy rocks in Utah or Arizona.Note to parents with young children, the roads are winding and lots of challenging turnings.

On any given day, especially a warm sunny day you will find people on the back roads, bicycling, driving, riding. Fun roads, lots of challenging turns, not for the faint of heart. In addition, the vistas of the Pacific Ocean epitomize why we live in Southern California. One highlight, "The Snake" where on the weekends a photographer posts up and catches people driving, riding, bicycling even skateboarding and you can purchase the digital photo on line for a nominal price. Lots of fun! Then when you are tired of driving, there are plenty of quaint places to eat and take a break.

There is too much here to lump the Santa Monica Mountains into one Review.. The question is what are you trying to do here, and what do you want to experience.. There is something here for everyone. If you want to have a smoothie at quarky restaurant in Topanga, you can do that, and have fun looking at the trees, and the steep canyons.. If you are looking for amazing sedimentary rock formations, from sandstone to conglomerates, etc... You can experience this too. If you are looking hiking trails, there are lots.. There aren't many that don't have views of housing projects, which is one of the downsides, but that is okay...The Santa Monica Mountains are part of the Transverse Range, which is an East-West trending mountain Range, and an Ancient part of the Sierra Nevada Batholith before being torn from that range by the Garlock Fault and ultimately the San Andreas Fault. The Santa Monica mountains are mostly sedimentary rocks, and mostly Oak Woodlands.. There a few pines here, but no pine forests. The altitude of the mountains are too low for sustained pine forests.There are many ways to access these mountains, from the many canyons accessed from the South, and West and North, you can enter the mountains. Beautiful green and lush oak forests on the coast to the drier oak forests more inland.Have fun.

We did not do much research or planning prior to our trip about which trails to hike or how to get to the best places in the Santa Monica Mountains, however had a great experience by just using the public transit to get us to the base of the Temescal Canyon Gateway Trails. We did not have a car, so this would be a great option for you if transportation is limited. We were able to take a very cheap bus fare ($2) in the morning out past Malibu (it was fairly quick as well for being in the LA area). It dropped us off right near the entrance of the trails. Hiking was free, as you enter it appears as a camp with log cabins and as you walk through this area you will come to a few different trail options. We just chose one and were not disappointed. We got some pretty great views of the coast. The terrain was decent, however tennis shoes are definitely necessary. We also saw a lot of hikers on the path with dogs on leashes, which is also a plus for pet-owners. Definitely worth the views near the top!

column2: If you just want to get away, try the Santa Monica Mountains
column3: Great place to hike all day, or walk with friends, or just by yourself.Be sure to bring and wear sunscreen, a hat, and water. One can access how to get here via Google Maps. Look up Westridge Rd in Mandeville Canyon. Take this road all the way to the end. You can park in the neighborhood and start hiking on Mandeville Fireroad. If you take this road to the end you the. Turn left on dirt Mullholland and access any number of other marked fire trails like Eagle Rock and such. The hike up to dirt Mulholland is a 700 foot elevation climb for 3.7 miles according to a Garman GPS Unit.If you car to complete this or more, may I also suggest bringing food as well.Dogs are common and friendly so if you bring yours, wear a camelbak so you will have enough water for you and your dog.

column2: Nature right in a city's backyard
column3: There are so many great hiking trails for all levels...short nature trails with difficulty ramping up to 'extremely strenuous'. The Santa Monica mountains are easily accessible from multiple points in the Pacific Palisades area and you can find that information online. I can't post a URL here but just search and there are a lot of sites with info.

column2: So many choices with views of LA
column3: The mountains are such a great way to walk and balance off some of the extra food eaten. Opportunity for photos is there. Some tracks are busy depending on the day.

column2: Circle X Ranch — a drive warning
column3: This is a "lovely when you get there" but a bear to reach destination.It was a 20-minute winding canyon road UP. It's wide enough to not be nervous in the face of oncoming traffic, not terribly steep or treacherous, either. However, it's a very stressful winding climb in any car.My jaw was tight after the constant zig-zagging route up. The same trip down was staring into the sun. I got quite a stress headache — not the desired outcome on an outdoor hike in the canyon.The top has parking, a restroom, picnic tables and a commemoration with a flag. It's often used for Boy Scouts.My friend took a lovely 2-hour trail and said it was quite steep. I enjoyed the quiet time sitting and decompressing from the journey up. I'd require the same (and a drink) after we drove down.

Make sure you leave earlier than later, especially on weekends. first time we left at 2pm and got stuck in very slow moving traffic. The second time we left at 9am to go to the Getty Villa on Monday--smooth sailing. We drove off season. Continued north after the Getty and drove back down for sunset! Gorgeous!

As the signs along the road say, Los Angeles is the only major city in the world bisected by a mountain range, which, of course, affords visitors some pretty spectacular views when the weather is clear. Although Mulholland Drive is the main artery through the city, many side routes open up the further west you follow the mountains toward the ocean, so you want to plan ahead to prevent taking wrong exits and roads to nowhere.Mulholland Drive east into LA is curvy and the driver has to remain alert; however, there are several pullouts (each with very limited parking), and the uniqueness of the location and views make this a must-do experience if you have the time. All of the names and locations you have always heard mentioned on television are here, and the trip gives first-time visitors a chance to put them all together.We chose to drive a loop that took us 4-5 hours from Santa Monica, to Mulholland Drive, through Malibu Canyon, past Pepperdine University, up to Carrillo Beach State Beach, along the Malibu coast and back to Santa Monica. Here is our route: Starting from the Santa Monica pier area, we took I-10 to 405, and followed the 405 north to exit 61.where we connected with Mulholland drive and followed it east to 101. We took 101 north and west to Topanga Canyon Road, which we followed a short distance to Mulholland Hwy west (different than Mulholland Road). We drove Mulholland Hwy to Malibu Canyon Road, which brought us out on CA 1 (Pacific Coast Hwy) at Pepperdine University. 15 minutes north on CA 1 is Carrillo State Beach, which provides a rocky coastline similar to what you might see further north near Monterey/Carmel. From Carrillo Beach we turned back south and followed CA 1 along the coast through Malibu back to Santa Monica. A fun adventure for those who like to do their own thing.
We drove up into the Santa Monica mountains and enjoyed the landscape and views. Lots of curves in the road, so don't expect to go fast but oh so worth it.

column2: Some of the Best Hiking Views in the World
column3: The following statement may surprise you. The Santa Monica Mountains overlooking LA are home to some of the most visually stunning hikes anywhere in the world. This judgment comes from someone who has hiked all over the world, including the Scottish Highlands, Hawaii, the Rockies, the Alps, the Himalaya and the Karakorum. I had no idea you could even hike right on the outskirts of this big city until a friend I was visiting turned me on to these. A whole series of hikes lead up from the west side of LA into these mountains providing incredible views of the coastline all the way from Santa Monica to Palos Verdes and inland to downtown LA and the San Gabriels. On a clear day Catalina Island is clearly in view. Two of the best hikes are through Temescal Canyon and to the old Nike missile station along Westridge. Los Liones is another. The views from many viewpoints along the way on each of these hikes are the equal of any in the world, believe me. The trails themselves are well maintained and easy on your legs. No rocky terrain, just smooth going underfoot. So if you live in the area or are just visiting LA and love to hike, head here. You will not be disappointed. Nor will forget the experience.

column2: Great hikes and always a good workout in nature
column3: Numerous trailheads which can be located at the California State Parks website are available. Bring a hat and good walking shoes or hiking boots and hit the trail.

Drove over the mountains on our way to the Reagan Library from Santa Monica. Very beautiful drive with beautiful views especially on a sunny day like we had. Roads were not scary as I had read elsewhere.

column2: Pacific Ocean with Santa Monica Mountains
column3: We have visited the Santa Monica Mountains several times. The mountains are at the Pacific Ocean edge. There is in the Malibu section of California.There are over 500 miles of hiking trails with amazing panoramic views.
very nice. the mountains are very nice and interesting to look at and drive up and down were ever you can

column2: A Unique Range With Reverse Majestic Views
column3: Most scenic mountain range offer majestic views from afar, but these offer them from within.Situated between the coast and ocean and the San Fernando and several adjacent inland valleys from its peaks and cliffs majestic views can be enjoyed from hundreds of locations from Hollywood through almost Oxnard.On the coast side their are views of the white beaches, blue Pacific and ocean islands, while on the valley side there are countless vistas that serve as lover's lanes overlooking these growing valleys especially after dark as the lights in the distant glimmer and twinkle.The many passes offer their own individual vistas of smaller valleys inside the range,
Love it here. Stayed for 4 nights in an airbnb home and managed to squeeze in a hike on Piuma Trail. Wish I could stay longer and explore more of the area.
We didn't do any hiking but just driving thru the mountains from Calabasses to Malibu was amazing. The canyons were so beautiful. We actually drove back thru the mountains so we could see it agai

Large area for easy to difficult hiking experiences with numerous view spots thrown in. Vegetation is So. Cal so this is arid country, not a Yosemite. Know where you're going beforehand and plan ahead - you'll have a nice hiking experience...

The hiking trails in the Santa Monica Mountains range from easy to hard, from short strolls to endurance hikes. You have to keep an eye out for rattlesnakes, but I hiked here for twenty years and have never been bitten. The land is lovely, oaks and eucalyptus, sage and manzanitas. Wildlife viewing is great: coyotes, foxes, raccoons, Bobcats. In the summer hike early because the afternoon sun is scorching in the canyons. A seasonal stream runs in the Topanga hiking area when there is not a drought which is very pretty. Watch out for poison oak near the streams. A peaceful place to strengthen your body and calm your mind, deep soul nourishment for wanderers and hikers.

However, there are some beautiful places to see. Soo a little more research, about driving is advisable. A drive through the Malibu mountains is great, the area encompasses 10's of thousands of acres, plan your trip, make the drive.
If you like Farmers Markets, you will LOVE this place on Wednesdays. Blocks and blocks of fresh fruits and veggies.Verty friendly vendors. Many samples.

column2: Take a nice drive into the mountains and along the coast
column3: Took a drive North on the Pacific Coast Highway from Santa Monica. Went North on Topanga Canyon Road, to 101 W, to Malibu Canyon Dr S, which takes you back to the Pacific Coast Highway in Malibu. Headed a little further north on the PCH and stopped at Paradise Cove for a great lunch. The Paradis Cove Cafe is right on the beach. You can eat inside or out. Outside is set up with tables, umbrellas and heaters if you need them--outside take your shoes off and sit with your feet in the sand. We headed a little further north after lunch before turning around. It made for a nice, leisure day.

The Santa Monica Mountains are a natural jewel located near the Greater Los Angeles Metro Area. Approximately 60,000 acres of open space are available for public recreation. Keep an eye out for rattlesnakes in April. The mountains are their natural habitat.

column2: Beautiful Mountains that go all the way to coast
column3: Lots of trails and hiking and small town visits. Can be alot of traffic on weekends, but during week best time to visit, and lots of trails for hiking, nice visit to the small art town of Topanga

We hiked on Sunday afternoon with our two teenagers. This is a popular, family friendly hike to a waterfall. There was only a trickle of water today due to the drought but worth the time. The trail head is off Winding Way road just off PCH. There is a small free parking lot or street parking along PCH. It is about 3 miles round trip. Allow about 2 hours. A great way ton get some exercise and see the SM moutains.

We drove through the mountains in Santa Monica a few times and it was always a treat. Stop and take some pictures or just find somewhere to hangout in the mountains over looking Santa Monica and the ocean. The mountains are visible from most places in Santa Monica

I have been using the series of trails for years. There are all types of terrain for a variety of interests and fitness levels. The views from certain sections are great with views of the Pacific. It is possible to hit the same or different paths and see new items every time. However , a couple of important points.For some reason there are dog owners who think it is a cool to leave their dogs off lease and roam on their own. This is not a good idea or safe. Dogs can get lost, get hurt and create a waste nuisance on the trails. These owners rarely pick up after their dogs.Also some dogs are frightening to people. Seeing a dog off leash can be scary for some and even dangerous. I have witnessed this several times where a unleashed dog threatens people or another dog.It is also against the law to have an untethered dog in the mountains.Be considerate about this and do not leave your dog running around.

column2: Hike with the dogs here all the time
column3: The SM Mountains are great, they are wide open and not too overrun. We bring the dogs all the time and they love it. Go see the missile launch place..
This is a very scenic drive. We travelled West and ended with a ride thru Pepperdine campus. It is beautiful.
Saddle Peak gives you a 270-degree view of the LA basin and the ocean. It's an unmatched view from anywhere else in the mountains.

column2: Take a scenic drive on Mulholland Highway!
column3: I'm from the mountains of Tennessee, so being able to see the mountains of California was wonderful. They are unique and beautiful in their own way. The mountains are great to see as a backdrop while on the beach, but it is also an adventure to go INTO the mountains like we did. It was a nice change to be able to escape in the peaceful mountains and get away from the crazy busy tourist attractions we had been visiting near the ocean.There are a lot of very scenic drives that you can take. We also noticed a lot of walking trails through the mountains if you're into hiking. There were also a lot of mountain bikers and motorcycle riders on the roads in the mountains.I highly recommend taking a scenic drive in a convertible like we did! The Pacific Coast Highway will lead you beside the ocean & mountains and then you can make a turn to drive up into the mountains. We took Mulholland Highway (NOTE: Mulholland Highway, not Mulholland Drive) and it was one of the highlights of my trip! A narrow, winding, curvy road with lots of hills and blind curves. It was filled with sports cars racing through the mountains. It looked like something straight out of a movie!And best of all? It's FREE!If you do take a scenic drive on Mulholland Highway....just be careful that you don't drive too fast because there are some tricky curves and we noticed several places with loose gravel in the road.

A truly beautiful and historic place. The wealth of good hikes in Southern California is under-appreciated, and those in the LA area get especially short shrift. The SMMs offer some of the most iconically Californian views available to casual hikers, and if you're overwhelmed by the congestion and sprawl for which LA is always derided, this is a nice reprieve.Many trails are easily accessed from the freeway and reasonably well-maintained roads in the mountains. Charmlee Wilderness Park is a good bet if you're less experienced or short on time - very beautiful trails with great views of the ocean and surrounding hills, on-shore whale-watching opportunities at the right time of year (we saw Grays in late December), and only 15 minutes from the 101. My pictures are from this area.This website is helpful for LA and beyond:http://www.modernhiker.com/area-maps/santa-monica-mountains/

column2: Miles and miles of trails and scenic drives
column3: I've noted previously here on TripAdvisor that my family pioneered Santa Monica in 1875 and that we've lived here along the bay since. In addition to the endless joys of Santa Monica beach life, is the amazing availability of recreational opportunities in the surrounding Santa Monica Mountains. There are dozens of great trails from easy to high-moderate whose trailheads begin at nearby Will Rogers State Park and go north and westward to Sycamore Canyon off the Pacific Coast Highway and beyond. The Santa Monica Mountains Conservancy oversees this huge swath of parkland and uses LAMountains.com for info - a website with a disappointing chock-a-block array of links that are anything but intuitive or simple to use, but that aside, if you poke around you'll find a variety of trails that lead to awesome views of the bay. From Santa Monica, I recommend the following trailheads: Will Rogers (easy), Bienvenida (easy),Westridge (easy) and for variety of efforts and views (and a waterfall), the Santa Ynez Canyon Trail. But for the more ambitious bring your mountain bike or consider the Mishe Mokwa trail which takes you to the peak of the highest mountain (3114') in the range where you can sign the book at the very top. I will always return.
A great way to blow the cobwebs away from the long flight the day before. The views from up the hill over Santa Monica & LA were stunning.
Many great traisl in the many canyons, well groomed, fairly well marked, Some are quite demanding (hills), all have good parking at their base.
Great vista views and coming together with nature..Thank goodness it has been preserved. It is an excellent place to hike

I wanted a less urban hike while visiting LA, and Solstice Canyon trail was it. Not too challenging, great scenery, and lots to explore. Two burned-out ranches along the trail remind you that this is wildfire territory. Most interesting was Robert's Ranch about 1.5 miles up the trail from where we parked. Nice ocean views along the trail. No admission fee to this recreation area.

The Santa Monicas are great for road and mtb cyling. As a part of California's transverse ranges, they are unusually steep with many canyons carving through the range.The range starts east of Hollywood and traverses some 40 miles until they are unmercifully chopped off by the Pacific Ocean. This sudden end of the range results in locations with incredible ocean views, and canyon roads with thrilling descents down to Pacific Coast Highway.The best cycling is west of the I-405, where Mulholland Highway (as oppose to Mulholland Drive) traverses across the range, ending up at Pacific Coast Highway.In either type of cycling, you will see many other cyclists taking advantage of the area. Motorists in the area are used to cyclists on the road, which is good for safety.To find good routes in the Santa Monicas, post a query in the Southern California section of BikeFourms.com

Most travelers who visit the Los Angeles area see the Santa Monica Mountains as the backdrop to Hollywood and the beach. But if you're a relatively fit person who enjoys serenity and you seek a fresh perspective of Southern California from downtown to Catalina, ditch the throngs of tourists on Venice Beach. Escape the carnival atmosphere and conspicuous consumption of Hollywood and Sunset. If you're a roadie or a mountain biker, rent a quality bike from Helen's Cycles in Santa Monica, Google the best road or mountain bike rides in the Santa Monica Mountains, pick the distance and difficulty that appeals to you and head for the hills. If you're a hiker or trail runner, get some water, Google Las Liones Trail and head up, up, up... to Temescal Overlook. Once there, you'll enjoy an expansive view of Los Angeles from downtown to Orange County, from the Palos Verdes Peninsula to Malibu. If it's a relatively clear day, you'll see Catalina and, likely, even little San Miguel Island a bit north. What you won't see or hear are crowds of people. If you're more adventurous or want to venture a bit further out, Google the Backbone Trail, which runs the length of the Santa Monica Mountains, and hike, run or bike one or more of it's many sections that can be accessed from various canyon roads. Will Rogers State Park contains the closest and easiest portion to access, but every section is unique and beautiful.

Santa Monica Mountains offer perfect hiking areas with amazing vistas of city and ocean views. It is best to view at sunset. Mountains are clean with well marked trails.

column2: Hike with Best Views: Los Liones Trailhead Behind Getty Villa
column3: You can hike in the Santa Monica mountains from this easy to access trailhead at the end of Los Liones road in Pacific Palisades and see the entire Los Angeles basin.Los Liones drive is off of Sunset Blvd. about a half mile east of Pacific Coast Highway. There are 3 parking lots along Los Liones plus lots of free street parking. There are bathrooms.The trailhead itself is at the very end of the road and is marked by a stone archway.It is a 1.5 mile hike to the top where there is a 360 degree panoramic vista; you can see the entire Los Angeles basin from the Wilshire Corridor to the Santa Monica Bay. On a clear day you will see the Palos Verdes Peninsula.The total trip takes about 1.5 hours - 30 minutes each way plus time to relax at the top. I would consider this trail of moderate difficulty. It is a steady uphill climb. There are some shady places right off the trail where you can rest on a big boulder, if needed.There is a bench at the top and lots of flat area if one wanted to take a picnic (although no shade). The trail is easy to navigate - saw one woman in flip flops. This trail works for runners as well as hikers.This trail is popular on the weekends so you won't be alone.Take water, sunscreen, hat, camera.This trail offers one of the best views of the city.

column2: Mountain Scenery Next to a Major City
column3: Santa Monica Mountains are located just west of Santa Monica, very close to the Los Angeles metropolitan area. The mountain range is right next to the Pacific and offers great views of the ocean and surrounding areas.I drove through the Santa Monica Mountains over a weekend in Los Angeles and I enjoyed every moment of my trip. I like visiting at least one place of natural scenery wherever I go and the Santa Monica Mountains seemed like a good choice. Living in a completely flat area like I do, it’s hard to imagine that such majestic mountains are right there, next to a major metropolitan area, but they are and they beckoned me to visit. The convenience to L.A. makes these mountains an easy place to get to and drive through so I gassed up the rental car and went on my way.Within the Santa Monica Mountains are a few state parks, a National Recreation area, hiking trails, and a few small villages. A hike affords the best views of the areas, but even the views from the car windows are nice. I drove from the north to the south and I loved the views of the mountains, trees, and countryside. I also liked the moment I reached the Pacific Ocean- it literally burst upon me as I circled a curve and came to the traffic light right there at the Pacific Coast highway.Mountain scenery is great and it’s especially memorable when you spend your days and nights living in a place that is completely flat. The Santa Monica Mountains provided me a nice nature fix and I plan to return on my next visit to the Los Angeles area.
Grand views of the mountains. Easy to reach .Just don't speed through them. Tricky turns.As pretty as they are in the day, it is great at night with all the lights.

column2: Scenic Mountains and Beautiful Ocean Together!
column3: I highly recommend a visit here. You don't even need to hike to enjoy it if you like driving scenic winding roads. The views on Mulholland Hwy. through the middle of the mountains here are more expansive than narrower Mulholland Dr. east of here in the Hollywood Hills. There is a recenly opened visitors center at King Gillette Ranch along Mulholland Hwy. just south of Las Virgenes Rd. There is a really helpful website at http://www.nps.gov/samo which has great map (the link is on the left side toward the bottom in the Park Tools section).
These winding roads near Santa Monica provide beautiful views and amazing scenery. It's hard to believe it's so close to Los Angeles. If you've got a free afternoon, it's a nice place for a drive.

column2: Great drive from Malibu to Santa Clarita the back way.
column3: I saw that the traffic on PCH was all chocked up , so decided to drive the backway home to my accomodation in Santa Clarita.You can get up close and friendly with moutain range the first 10 miles or so from Malibu.Majestic . At a later date will take the turn off and study this great range up close.

Whenever I stay at my Lowes hotel I can't help myself from wanting to look towards the mountains, whether day or dusk... because they are fantastic! The backdrop against the ocean lets me know I'n not in Jersey! Peaceful and great to daydream with.
Great hiking. Many trails ranging from a small nature trail to several miles long. We took the waterfall hike. There was no water, but the hike down to the canyon floor was scenic.

We weren't sure where to start exploring the Santa Monica Mountains! Having read a review on Trip Advisor, we opted for Will Rogers State Park. The trails were easy and clearly signed. The views were spectacular! We would have liked to have spent longer in the area as we love hiking but we managed two wonderful trails in an afternoon. Get out of the city and explore this incredible wilderness.

Hiking to the top of the Canyons in the Santa Monica mountains gives you a great view from Santa Monica/Malibu all the way out to Downtown LA (40 minutes away) Some hikes are easier than others! It's worth the trek!

column2: Get up early for the sunrise
column3: The sun rises here around 6am. Take a ride to the Santa Monica Mountains down Pacific Highway and then up into the mountains to catch the first rays of sunlight. Views a well worth the early start.

I love hiking in the Santa Monica Mountains. I grew up in Santa Monica and was a runner so I have seen a lot of them. If you are a tourist, the best place to start is Will Rodgers State Park. They have trials that are clearly laid out and provide beautiful vantage points. There is also a bathroom and water fountains. Most hikes are gentle enough to take kids and dogs are allowed.

column2: Great Place to Get Back to Nature
column3: We hiked in the Franklin Canyon Park, which is part of the Santa Monica Mountains. The weather was beautiful the day we were there, so we never got too hot. It's a fun day trip.
We were able to take a ride on Mulholland Drive and made several stops to enjoy the views. It was wonderful to be able to take in all the beauty.
The Santa Monica Mountains have easy trails as well as more difficult ones. When you are there the views are plentiful. The breeze comes off the water and it is supposed to be the best air around La.
Good clean beach with lots of other people around It is safe but bring your own chairs and an umbrella Nearby refreshment and bathrooms

I was born in Santa Monica and used to drive through these mountains all the time. Before the freeway was built, there was just Sepulveda Blvd that went through to the San Fernando Valley, and it was a lovely drive. One place you don't want to miss when in the Santa Monica area.

If your'e in town and wanting a lively hike to burn off all the delicious meals you are eating while in town, then the Santa Monica Mountains is the place for you! There are gentle hikes and challenging hikes and the views are unparalleled. I would say go with friends, in the unlikely case that you get lost on a trail, but there are usually hikers around that can help you find your way back. The ocean breeze is the big attraction, you don't get that at Runyan Canyon LOL! Enjoy!

A great place for a short or long hike. Easily accessible from the city. And you are in another world walking amongst the hills. Great views over the ocean, downtown and suburbs. Highly recommended to get away from it all!
Driving thru the mountains was such a joy for my granddaughter and her friends...they oh's and awed the whole trip up the coast.

column2: Good trail around Will Rogers Park
column3: We accessed the trails via Will Rogers Park, and walked up to Inspiration Point, where we had a fabulous, 360-degree view of Santa Monica, West Los Angeles, Century City, Santa Monica Mountains, and, of course, the Pacific Ocean. Considering how beautiful the scenery is and how many people live in Los Angeles, I was shocked that we only ran into a few other day hikers. The trail we were on hooked up with the Topanga Canyon trail, and it looked like you could go just about anywhere through the Santa Monica Mountains.

Really fun.... technical drive up in the mountains, but wow the view is spectacular. We even saw a storm roll into the mountains, the clouds poured right on top of us while we were hiking the Topanga trail.

For Los Liones Canyon Trail ---Parker Mesa CanyonI drove up north on Paseo Miramar until I hit the dead end. Once at the dead end, turn left and you'll the entrance to the trail. I thought I was getting lost coming here for the first time. I'm sure there's another entrance but this is where my GPS lead me when adding yelp's listed address.What a great workout! I would rate this trail at a Medium difficulty level. It's a paved, dirt road and it's fairly easy but you'll definitely work a sweat going up and down the trail. Definitely a good 5 mile roundtrip workout for anyone.I went on a nice, breezy day with almost no sun so had no difficult going up the trail. If it's blazing hot, would highly recommend you come prepared with sunscreen and water.Loved that this trail wasn't crowded and there was plenty of parking on the street up the hill. There's a beautiful view of Santa Monica, Downtown, and the ocean the minute you get on that trail. In fact, I saw several groups of people there solely to take pictures 0.2 miles into the trail.

column2: Splendid View and not all level trails
column3: Actually this is a very big mountain includes a lot of trails. So it's a little hard to come up with a general review on the whole site. You could try HikeSpeak to get detail about each trail. Just the pics won't be so updated like TripAdvisor. We took Los Leones Canyon trail in a little cloudy day which I believe is right weather for hiking since I don't enjoy the sunshine too much. The trail is 2 miles long one-way and not too hard or steep, but a little dirty and slippery, so remember to get some good hiking shoes. And when you reach the Parker Mesa Overlook, there's a bench which you could get the whole Santa Monica Bay in your sight. Good spot to relax. Higher is a little steeper but could manage. Nice little trail for neighborhood and family too.
Spectacular backdrop for LA. Lots of fun driving through them but you got to be careful because the CA drivers are crazy! Take your time. The canyon roads are not for the faint of heart.
just wanted to walk the beach, hear the waves and breath in the sea air. beach is very clean not too crowded in January. Perry's on the walkway will set up chairs and cater to you.
The views are unbelievable, it's like something out of a movie there is nothing to dislike!! The weather was great!
I loved the hike, but getting here was a bit tricky and it was busy with people, both locals and tourists alike. I recommend going up here on week days and be prepared to get decent directions.

I hike them on a weekly basis and love the weather. They don't have the greenery that places with seasons do, but there are sooo many trails, soo many that are dog friendly, and generally good parking options.

Stunning view from the top, the mountains' area is just a good spot to take a walk solo and momentarily escape from the pollution of the city.The trails are wide and there are plenty of spots for camping and horseriding; however, before taking a walk is important to have a map and know exactly which trail to follow.

The Santa Monica Mountains is a large, mostly natural area exhibiting a rare Mediterranean environment which offers a multitude of recreational activates from hiking, camping, motoring, horseback riding and much more just northwest of LA. Composed of many public lands and some private lands encompassing well know and lesser know parks, valleys and roads, many used for filming familiar movies and shows, and reaches down to the ocean where there are many famous beaches. Highlights include Paramount Ranch (Dr. Quinn and many films), Malibu State Park (M*A*S*H, Planet of the Apes), King Gillette Ranch (The Biggest Loser), the famous Mulholland Drive and the Hollywood Sign, the Mulholland Highway (which we preferred), Topanga State Park, Runyon Canyon Park and Will Rogers State Park. There is much more and if one is spending any time in LA, one should spend at least a day exploring and enjoying the area and visiting one of the famous beaches at the base of the mountains. We would recommend stopping by the Interagency Visitor Center next to King Gillette Ranch to see the exhibits, introductory movie and help with planning your visit including current programs and events.

We are so fortunate to have the lovely Santa Monica Mountains to play in. Do a Google search to see all the fantastic hiking trails. I enjoy hiking from January to June because I favor wildflowers, butterflies, and other nature (not into the "long view" so hoofing to the top of a mountain is not entertaining to me). There are some great wildflower hikes throughout.Take the trailhead from Pacific Coast Highway so you can enjoy views of the Pacific along your hikes.Some trails take you through filming locations; the most famous is Malibu Creek, where MASH used to be filmed.If you visit LA to do more than looking for celebrities or theme parks, please do a search to find your bliss in the Santa Monica Mountains.

I go hiking in different areas of the Santa Monica mountains on a regular basis, each weekend almost. Malibu or Topanga Canyon are the most popular access points for me since I live here. There's plenty of peaceful hiking trails for outings, with excellent viewpoints, depending on how high you'd like to go up there.

My wife & I wanted to get out of the city for a bit and see the amazing views of the Santa Monica mountains, so off we went, drove for an hour and a half and parked up at the parking area just after Circle X Ranch, armed with a pre-planned 7 mile route from a hiking website that was to take us across three different peaks. And walk it we did - but during a heatwave, with no hats, and nowhere near enough water. By the end it was getting a little hairy and we were just glad to be safe and back in civilisation.If you're spending some time in LA then do yourself a favour and get into these mountains - the views are incredible. Just research a good route in advance, make sure you're comfortable with the distances and the heights involved, and if you think you have enough water, double it and maybe add a little more. This is not a place you want to get stranded!

column2: Endless walking in Santa Monica, California
column3: Most tourists would not find them, but seek them out and be rewarded with endless walking paths throughout the SM hills and valleys. Get amongst nature for some heart wrenching hills and superb views.
